ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My grammar and reading skills are better than ever! I loved all of the stories that we read. I finally feel confident in writing in French. So it can only get better as I go into 150.

I definitely strengthened my French grammatical knowledge, as well as my confidence reading, writing, and speaking French. I also think I have a deeper understanding of some different French-speaking countries.

Improved my French language skills, re-enforcing old grammar skills and combining them with new ones. Improved conversational skills. Also learn a lot of interesting things about WW2 in France I didn't know before.
Reading, speaking, fine tuning grammar

I learned how to write intellectually in French. Going into the course, writing was not my strong suit, but with the help and encouragement of Madame Koizim, I greatly improved my writing abilities. I was also able to work on speaking and presenting in the course. I read more than I ever had, and learned without realizing it.
This course helps you reach an advanced level of French. I learned a wide variety of vocabulary and grammar concepts, and I also immensely improved my speaking, listening, writing and reading skills.
This class is all about being able to speak and understand spoken french. I feel like it is taught very well for getting to this goal. Reading comprehension is also a big part of the class.

I reviewed grammar rules I learned in high school and learned new ones as well.  I feel much more comfortable reading literature in French and speaking the language, too, as a result of the discussions in class as well as the speaking portions that formed part of the assessments throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really like that the class meets every day, I think that really helps with my language comprehension and speaking abilities. Overall, I really enjoyed most of the readings. The reading load was really heavy at times but that's pretty expected.
Testing format was fairly frustrating for me, likely mostly due to having to do it online etc. Mostly I think it's a really well done course.

Strengths - madame is a light! she's so much fun, very knowledgeable as well. the textbook is also one of the best I've had 
Weaknesses: perhaps it wasn't always clear when and what had to be submitted when and where.... but it doesn't really impact the experience. the texts we read were also just really sad for the most part.

The biggest strength in the course was the availability of Madame Koizim. It felt okay to be unsuccessful with conjugations and to get something wrong. She is a very, very encouraging professor. I also think the amount of reading is a big strength. I enjoyed how much I could successfully read at the end of the day. I was amazed by the speed of our progress and the discussions that Madame brought to the class. It was a conversation about the topics and not a guess what I'm thinking kind of course. I also loved the small presentations we got to do where we could learn about something we really care about in the language.

This course is very well structured, it gives you a clear idea of what you are going to learn and how practicing those concepts everyday in and outside of class will get you there. This course does an excellent job of getting your French to an advanced level, and all of the texts and discussions we had were really engaging. Just one suggestion, for the Un Sac de Billes reading, personally I had a hard time keeping up with the reading assignments, and my classmates also expressed the same concerns. I don't know if it's possible but if there was some way for the reading assignments to be a bit shorter, I think that could help students a lot.
There is a lot of work required for this class. Like a lot. But once you get into the rhythm of it it's fine. The professors make it all worth it, especially Mme. Koizim.

I would say that the support this course offered was a major strength. Because this class meets every weekday, students find themselves in a tight-knit community that encourages mistakes to ultimately master the vocabulary and grammar points covered in the class. I found myself mainly learning the grammar outside of class, however, and would have liked a bit more structure in that aspect during our live virtual meetings such as implementation of short mini-presentations.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Because we always had reading assignments before class, speaking in French during class was easy, as it was guided by stories with particular vocabulary to know. Loved it

I honestly think a zoom seminar works really well, especially with a good teacher. We sometimes used the breakout rooms or the chat but even just the standard zoom room worked pretty well for class. f
Meeting everyday and speaking was good. There was some difficulty with OWL but that's all.
I think this class adapted well to the pandemic. No complaints.
Mme Koizim was brilliant in getting us to participate in virtual class whether we wanted to or not. Her office hours were an amazing resource as well.

I thought that the discussions of the readings were perfect for understanding the literature and thus allowed everyone in the class to be on the same page. I also greatly appreciated the time we took to go over and analyze the grammar problems on the homework as those conversations and the points other students contributed during those conversations expanded my interpretations of the practice problems that ultimately allowed me to master the material.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely especially if you can score Madame Koizim! It was just a really fun class and you never feel like youre wasting your time doing busy work.

I would, but only if they were excited about really learning more French. It's pretty work intensive, so even though the teacher(s) are really engaging and supportive, it's only really worth it if you're eager to learn more! But if you are into French, I think it's a really good class.

Yes, I would recommend this course. Although I took this course to complete my language requirement, this was the course that made me enjoy learning French. One thing I would point out for consideration is the courseload. This course meets everyday and attendance is required. There is pretty much homework on a daily basis, and there will be tests at a higher frequency than other classes. However, I found my French skills improving drastically after this class as it built on many foundational skills.
absolutely, you get to read some cool things and learn from a great prof.
Yes, definitely. I would recommend it to someone if they are willing to put in the effort to master French concepts.

Yes I would! Generally speaking, I think you should learn a language that you are passionate about. So, if you're passionate about French, definitely take this course and French at Yale, you will be so proud of yourself and your improvements in the language.
If you really want to learn french, yes. It's going to be a lot of work, don't get me wrong, and you will read a lot of sad french stories, but it's worth it. Especially if you have Mme. Koizim!

Yes, of course! This was the first course that I have taken at Yale that truly made me feel close to my peers. We all made mistakes throughout the semester, but we all learned from them and from each other. While you may have reviewed much of the grammar material in the past, you have the opportunity to improve upon your speaking abilities in this course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Virtual seminar along with online office hours.
